channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: The Week Ahead: September 20
item.description: TV shows returning this week: Survivor, The Great British Bake Off, The Voice, Dancing With the Stars Europe.  Golf’s Ryder Cup starts Friday, pitting the US vs.   Everything else: Fall officially begins on Wednesday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 20
item.description: (GQ) Read: How Lil Nas X mastered the art of attention. He said he could support one as more evidence rolls in.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: House Democrats Will Try to Suspend the Debt Ceiling as Yellen Warns of "Catastrophe"
item.description: Without suspending the debt ceiling, the US wouldn’t be able to borrow money to pay its bills—and things would get ugly if that happened.   The Business Roundtable, an influential group of top executives, wrote that failure to suspend the debt ceiling could “produce an otherwise avoidable crisis and pose unacceptable risk” to the country’s economy and markets. House Democrats will make moves this week to suspend the $28.5 trillion debt ceiling as an October deadline fast approaches. Instead, it’s about spending Congress has already authorized, such as paying out Social Security.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Child Care Job Crisis
item.description: Big picture: The Treasury Department has called the child care system “unworkable” in its current form.  Child care workers regularly make less than $15/hour, lower than most retail jobs at this point. Child care is down 126,700 employees since before the pandemic, a drop of more than 10%.  Looking ahead...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Arc de Triomphe Gets Wrapped in Massive Art Undertaking
item.description: Paris’s Arc de Triomphe has been transformed into an epic art installation inspired by Christo and Jeanne-Claude, now-deceased artists known for their larger-than-life pieces (like The Gates in NYC’s Central Park).
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 18
item.description: (Ed Conway)  Read: Why we need to start thinking about concrete.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Chinese Property Developer On the Brink of Default
item.description: After news spread of the company’s mounting debt, investors showed up at the company’s Shenzhen headquarters beginning late last week demanding money they’re owed from the firm.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Supply Chain Snags Cause Major Port Congestion
item.description: The queue of container ships waiting to enter Los Angeles’s and Long Beach’s neighboring ports hit an all-time high of 65 vessels this past week, and they’ll wait an average of 8.7 days to deliver their cargo.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: FDA Advisory Panel: Boomers Can Get Boosters
item.description: 20, but some health experts (including two senior FDA officials) pushed back, saying there wasn’t enough data yet to show a third shot was necessary. That decision throws a wrench in the Biden administration’s plans to roll out boosters to US adults beginning next week.  Booster boosters also point to data from Israel, a country that has given booster shots to nearly 3 million people in the past several months. Other loud voices have urged the US to add a third shot to the standard vaccine regimen—voices like the vaccine makers themselves.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.description: After news spread of the company’s mounting debt, investors showed up at the company’s Shenzhen headquarters late last week and this week demanding money they’re owed from the firm.

item.title: In Atlanta, a Tech Hub Rises Among the Peach Orchards
item.description: In other Atlanta tech deals last week... Microsoft will hire 1,500 people at its new Atlanta office, Apple is partnering on a $50 million tech center, and Airbnb, explicitly citing the prevalence of Black talent in Atlanta, also plans to open a hub in the city. The city is home to a cluster of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), including Clark Atlanta University, Morehouse College, and Spelman College.  Tech companies that have pledged to increase diversity in their workforces are eyeing Atlanta’s Black engineering talent. A recent string of deals has put Atlanta on the map as a growing power player in the US technology industry.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Make It Work
item.description: We have an unlimited PTO policy. How do I ask for days off? Ask Shane here. One thing that’s not unlimited is your mental and physical health, so don’t cheat yourself out of the time you need to properly recharge. Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. HR Brew. Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? Try asking about the minimum amount of PTO they would expect you to take. They’ve empowered you to determine how much time off you can realistically take without compromising that work—and while I’d recommend a more modest approach until you get a feel for where that line is, I don’t think a few days off during the holidays is an unreasonable place to start. It’s a good move to ask your manager if they have any preferences.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: FDA Advisory Panel: Boomers Can Get Boosters
item.description: Last month, President Biden said the booster shot rollout would begin September 20, but some health experts (including two senior FDA officials) have pushed back, saying there wasn’t enough data yet to show a third shot was necessary. Other loud voices have urged the US to add a third shot to the standard vaccine regimen—voices like those of the vaccine makers themselves. That decision throws a wrench i the Biden administration’s plans to roll out boosters to US adults beginning next week.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers With...Kat Cole
item.description: But the aroma of Auntie Anne’s makes me want to eat a pretzel, like, “Must. And people are going to pay a premium for it. Like, I just got opportunities earlier than most people would. And where experience is valued, there still might be some automation in a piece of the production but that human element is going to be increasingly cherished. Probably every two months. Do you think your original position as a Hooters server will exist 10 years from now? What I think people might miss about my two long stints at the same parent enterprise is I was in super high-growth companies, and so really I was running multiple different companies—I just didn’t have to leave the entity to do it. The Cinnabon aroma is a bit more magic, and intoxicating, and the Auntie Anne’s aroma is kind of like, “Take all my money.” It’s indulgent, and I am satisfied almost just from that aroma. Then, she joined Focus Brands, the parent company of Cinnabon, Auntie Anne’s, and other chains, where she became President and COO. Yes, I learned over time to be a really thoughtful, caring, and driven leader, but you cannot remove a high-growth company from that equation.  Yes, I would make it fully remote, and I would put in some really killer and regular moments of in-person connection when it would be safe and possible.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Federal Reserve Announces Ethics Investigation After Regional Bank Officials’ Trading
item.description: The Federal Reserve said yesterday that it’s breaking out the ol’ ethics guidelines to look into rules surrounding senior Fed officials' personal investments.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: France Calls US-Australia-UK Submarine Deal “A Stab in the Back”
item.description: Why France is furious: Australia had signed a contract with a French shipbuilder in 2016 to build nonnuclear submarines, but this week decided to ditch France in order to get its hands on more advanced, nuclear-powered ones.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: “Tax the Rich” Echoes 10 Years After Occupy Wall Street
item.description: Occupy’s legacyPeople disagree about the long-term impact of Occupy Wall Street, with some calling it a flop and others arguing that it laid the groundwork for other progressive social and political movements.    On September 17, 2011, Occupy Wall Street began. —NF “I think if you look at the last 10 years, activism has not worked,” he said.  In 2011, Time magazine named “The Protestor” as its Person of the Year.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Microsoft Goes Completely Passwordless
item.description: It’s much harder to swipe a user’s fingerprint or a code sent directly to their phone. —MM Bottom line: Microsoft said that the rapid shift to digital during the pandemic accelerated its timeline for the rollout.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.description: More people visited the park last month—921,844—than in any August on record, park officials said. (Julia Hobsbawm on Twitter) Watch: An excellent back-to-office video.

item.title: Canva Becomes the Fifth-Most Valuable Private Startup in the World
item.description: —MM Canva will use the new funding to double its 2,000-person staff over the next year and expand into web design and video editing tools.  Looking ahead...
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Casino Stocks Plunge Over Fears of a Crackdown on Macau
item.description: US casino stocks with exposure to Macau, such as Wynn, also tumbled yesterday. —NF Macau’s casinos rake in around $37 billion in annual revenue, roughly 5x more than the Vegas Strip. Zoom out: Macau is to Las Vegas as Las Vegas is to Atlantic City. less gambling.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Food Delivery Apps Are Suing NYC and Other Cities
item.description: What delivery apps like DoorDash are angry about is that leaders in NYC and SF traced over their commission cap laws in Sharpie even after restaurants reopened. The other lawsuit, which saw DoorDash, GrubHub, and Uber Eats join forces, concerns commission caps, or the percentage of a food order’s total that delivery apps can charge restaurants for their services.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Canva Becomes the Fifth-Most Valuable Private Startup in the World

item.title: Casino Stocks Plunge Over Fears of a Crackdown on Macau
item.description: US casino stocks with exposure to Macau, such as Wynn, also tumbled yesterday. A Bloomberg index of the six Macau casino operators plummeted 23%, the biggest one-day fall on record. —NF Macau’s casinos rake in around $37 billion in annual revenue, roughly 5x more than the Vegas Strip.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Food Delivery Apps Are Suing NYC and Other Cities
item.description: What delivery apps like DoorDash are particularly angry about is that leaders in NYC and San Francisco traced over their commission cap laws in Sharpie even after restaurants reopened. The other lawsuit, which saw DoorDash, GrubHub, and Uber Eats join forces, concerns commission caps, or the percentage of a food order’s total that delivery apps can charge restaurants for their services.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Amazon Will Hire a Hartford, CT
item.description: Amazon said it will add 125,000 delivery and warehouse workers in the US ahead of the busy holiday shopping season. Pretty soon, everyone will be an Amazon employee. Well, Amazon plans to open 100 new logistics facilities this month alone. – NF
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 15
item.description: Quote: “Starting with boosters, especially giving it to healthy populations, is really not right.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook Knows Instagram is Toxic to Teens, Leaked Documents Reveal
item.description: “People talk about Instagram like it’s a drug.  Leaked documents reviewed by WSJ show that, despite knowing the harmful impacts of Instagram on teens, Facebook has taken few actions to make it less toxic and protect its most vulnerable users.
item.author: Sherry Qin
